meta.title: ETHICS: Ethical and Professional Standards Practice Drill
meta.description: 20 practice problems covering Level II Ethical and Professional Standards.

blocks.content:
## Ethical and Professional Standards Practice Drill

This set contains 20 problems covering the Code of Ethics, Standards of Professional Conduct, Guidance for Standards, and application scenarios. Level II ethics questions present more nuanced, fact-pattern-based scenarios that require careful analysis of competing obligations.

problems.question: Maria Vasquez, CFA, is an analyst at a sell-side firm. She discovers that a colleague has been front-running client orders based on the firm's research reports. Maria reports the misconduct to her supervisor, who dismisses her concerns and tells her to 'focus on her own work.' Maria's most appropriate next step is to:
options: A) Accept the supervisor's decision and take no further action
B) Escalate the matter to the firm's compliance department or legal counsel, and consider dissociating from the activity
C) Immediately resign from the firm and report to CFA Institute
problems.explanation: Under Standard I(A) Knowledge of the Law and Standard IV(A) Loyalty, Maria must not knowingly participate in or assist violations. When her direct supervisor dismisses the concern, she should escalate to compliance, legal counsel, or senior management. She should also consider whether her continued association constitutes participation in the violation. If the firm fails to act, she may need to dissociate (which could include resignation). Option A violates her duty to not participate in violations. Option C is premature -- she should exhaust internal escalation first.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply Standard I(A) when a supervisor dismisses a report of misconduct

problems.question: James Chen, CFA, manages a hedge fund. He discovers material nonpublic information (MNPI) about a company when the CFO accidentally sends him an email containing next quarter's earnings results (which are significantly above consensus). James should:
options: A) Trade on the information because he received it accidentally, not through any wrongful act
B) Refrain from trading and place the security on a restricted list, notifying his compliance department
C) Share the information with his research team so they can update their models
problems.explanation: Under Standard II(A) Material Nonpublic Information, a CFA charterholder must not act or cause others to act on MNPI regardless of how it was obtained. The accidental nature of receipt does not create an exception. James must: (1) not trade, (2) not communicate the information, and (3) notify compliance to place the security on a restricted list. Option A incorrectly assumes the 'mosaic theory' exception applies to accidentally received MNPI. Option C would violate the prohibition on tipping.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply Standard II(A) to accidentally received MNPI

problems.question: Susan Park, CFA, is a portfolio manager who also serves on the board of a public company. At a board meeting, she learns that the company plans to acquire a competitor at a significant premium. Susan holds shares of both companies in her personal account and in client portfolios. Her most appropriate course of action is to:
options: A) Sell the acquiring company's shares from all accounts before the announcement to avoid losses
B) Disclose the conflict to her employer, refrain from trading either security in personal and client accounts, and ensure the securities are on the restricted list
C) Trade only in client accounts because her fiduciary duty to clients supersedes the MNPI prohibition
problems.explanation: Susan faces both MNPI restrictions (Standard II(A)) and conflict of interest issues (Standard VI(A) Disclosure of Conflicts). She must: (1) not trade either security in any account (personal or client), (2) disclose the board position conflict to her employer, (3) have both securities placed on the firm's restricted list. The acquisition plan is MNPI regardless of the account type. Option A is insider trading. Option C incorrectly prioritizes fiduciary duty over the law -- there is no exception to the MNPI rule for client accounts.
problems.learningOutcome: Navigate conflicts between board membership, MNPI, and fiduciary duty

problems.question: An analyst publishes a research report recommending 'Buy' on a pharmaceutical stock. The report cites three published clinical studies and the analyst's own proprietary model. The analyst does not mention that one of the three studies was later retracted due to data fabrication. The analyst:
options: A) Violated Standard V(A) Diligence and Reasonable Basis because the retracted study undermines the research foundation
B) Did not violate any standard because the retraction occurred after the studies were initially peer-reviewed
C) Violated Standard V(B) Communication with Clients because the report was too technical
problems.explanation: Standard V(A) requires a reasonable and adequate basis for investment recommendations. If a key supporting study has been retracted, the analyst's basis is materially weakened. The analyst has a duty to verify the current status of referenced research and to update the recommendation if the basis changes. Citing a retracted study without noting the retraction misleads readers. Option B incorrectly suggests that initial peer review immunizes the analyst from future developments. Option C misidentifies the violated standard.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply Standard V(A) Diligence and Reasonable Basis to research recommendations

problems.question: Robert Kim, CFA, changes his rating on a stock from 'Buy' to 'Sell' based on deteriorating fundamentals. Before publishing the change, he calls his three largest institutional clients to inform them of the impending downgrade. Robert has most likely violated:
options: A) Standard III(B) Fair Dealing by selectively disseminating the rating change to favored clients
B) No standard, because institutional clients always receive research before retail clients
C) Standard III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, and Care by changing the rating without client approval
problems.explanation: Standard III(B) Fair Dealing requires that members deal fairly with all clients when disseminating investment recommendations or taking investment action. Selectively pre-notifying large clients gives them an unfair advantage to act before smaller clients. The standard does not require simultaneous delivery but prohibits intentional discrimination. Robert should disseminate the change to all clients at the same time. Option B is factually incorrect -- there is no such exception. Option C misapplies the standard -- analysts do not need client approval for rating changes.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply Standard III(B) Fair Dealing to selective dissemination

problems.question: A portfolio manager receives a gift of a luxury watch (valued at $8,000) from a broker after directing a large block of trades to that broker. The manager did not disclose the gift to her employer. She has most likely violated:
options: A) Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity, and Standard IV(B) Additional Compensation Arrangements
B) Standard III(A) only, because the gift does not affect her investment process
C) No standard, because the gift was received after the trades were executed
problems.explanation: The luxury watch creates the appearance (if not the reality) of a conflict of interest. Standard I(B) requires maintaining independence and objectivity -- accepting expensive gifts from brokers who benefit from trade flow threatens both. Standard IV(B) requires written consent from the employer before accepting compensation or benefits from third parties. The timing (after trades) does not eliminate the conflict -- it creates an incentive for future preferential treatment. Option B minimizes the gift's significance. Option C incorrectly relies on timing to excuse the conflict.
problems.learningOutcome: Identify violations related to gifts and additional compensation

problems.question: A CFA charterholder writes in her LinkedIn profile: 'Sarah Lee, CFA -- Top-ranked analyst, guaranteeing superior returns through advanced AI-driven models.' This statement most likely violates:
options: A) Standard VII(B) Reference to CFA Institute because of incorrect CFA designation usage
B) Standard I(C) Misrepresentation because of the guarantee of superior returns
C) Both Standard I(C) and Standard VII(B)
problems.explanation: The phrase 'guaranteeing superior returns' violates Standard I(C) Misrepresentation because no investment approach can guarantee returns. This creates false expectations. The CFA designation usage ('Sarah Lee, CFA') is actually correct -- it is used as an adjective/title after the name. If it said 'Sarah Lee, a CFA' or 'CFA Sarah Lee,' that would violate VII(B). Option A incorrectly identifies a VII(B) violation when the usage appears correct. Option C partially correct on I(C) but the CFA usage is proper.
problems.learningOutcome: Identify misrepresentation and proper CFA designation usage

problems.question: An analyst uses a complex quantitative model to generate investment recommendations. The model was developed by a third-party vendor and the analyst does not fully understand its methodology. She discloses in her reports that 'recommendations are model-driven' but does not explain the model's limitations. She has most likely violated:
options: A) Standard V(A) Diligence and Reasonable Basis because she lacks understanding of the methodology underlying her recommendations
B) No standard, because using third-party models is standard industry practice
C) Standard V(B) Communication only, because the disclosure was insufficient
problems.explanation: Standard V(A) requires the analyst to have a reasonable and adequate basis for recommendations. Using a model without understanding its methodology, assumptions, and limitations means the analyst cannot assess whether the output is reasonable. She cannot distinguish valid signals from model errors. Simply disclosing that recommendations are 'model-driven' does not fulfill the duty of diligence. Option B ignores the duty to understand tools used. Option C identifies a secondary issue but the primary violation is lack of reasonable basis.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply diligence requirements when using third-party quantitative models

problems.question: An investment bank analyst participates in writing the IPO prospectus for a company while simultaneously writing a 'Buy' recommendation on the same company for the firm's research department. This arrangement most likely violates:
options: A) Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity because the analyst's research independence is compromised by the investment banking relationship
B) No standard, as long as the analyst discloses the dual role
C) Standard VI(B) Priority of Transactions because the firm will trade before clients
problems.explanation: An analyst who participates in the IPO process cannot produce independent, objective research on the same company. The investment banking fee creates a powerful incentive to issue a favorable recommendation. Firewalls (information barriers) between investment banking and research exist specifically to prevent this type of conflict. Even with disclosure, the dual role fundamentally compromises objectivity. Option B underestimates the severity -- disclosure alone is insufficient when objectivity is structurally impossible. Option C addresses trading priority, not research independence.
problems.learningOutcome: Identify independence and objectivity violations in investment banking conflicts

problems.question: A portfolio manager has two client accounts with similar investment objectives. A hot IPO allocation becomes available for only one account. The manager allocates it to the larger account because the management fee on that account is higher. The manager has most likely violated:
options: A) Standard III(B) Fair Dealing by allocating based on fee revenue rather than a fair allocation policy
B) No standard, because larger accounts typically receive larger allocations
C) Standard III(C) Suitability, because IPOs may not be suitable for either account
problems.explanation: Standard III(B) requires fair dealing among clients. Allocating IPO shares based on fee revenue (benefiting the manager's firm) rather than a predetermined, systematic allocation policy (pro-rata, rotational, or random) discriminates against the smaller client. Both accounts have similar objectives and should have fair access. Option B conflates account size with fair allocation -- size-based allocation is acceptable only as part of a documented pro-rata policy, not fee-based favoritism. Option C changes the issue from allocation fairness to suitability.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply fair dealing principles to IPO allocation decisions

problems.question: A CFA charterholder working at a wealth management firm discovers that her colleague has been churning client accounts to generate excessive commissions. The colleague is not a CFA charterholder. The CFA charterholder's obligations under the Code and Standards include:
options: A) No obligation because the colleague is not a CFA charterholder
B) A duty to report the misconduct through appropriate channels and to not participate in or benefit from the activity
C) A duty to report the colleague directly to CFA Institute
problems.explanation: Under Standard I(A), members must not knowingly participate in or assist any violation of applicable laws, rules, or regulations. Churning is a violation of securities regulations. The CFA charterholder must take steps to address the misconduct: report through internal channels (compliance, management), refuse to participate, and consider dissociation if the firm does not act. The duty exists regardless of the colleague's CFA status. Option A incorrectly limits obligations to interactions with other CFA members. Option C overstates the duty -- there is no requirement to report non-members to CFA Institute, though internal and regulatory reporting may be required.
problems.learningOutcome: Determine obligations when observing misconduct by non-CFA colleagues

problems.question: David Wong, CFA, is reviewing a company's proxy statement for a shareholder vote. He discovers that management is proposing a compensation package with excessive stock options, poison pill provisions, and a staggered board -- all of which he believes are not in shareholders' best interests. As a portfolio manager voting proxies on behalf of clients, David should:
options: A) Vote with management because proxy voting is not part of the investment management function
B) Vote against the proposals in accordance with his fiduciary duty to clients, following the firm's proxy voting policies
C) Abstain from voting to avoid taking a position on corporate governance
problems.explanation: Standard III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, and Care requires the portfolio manager to act in clients' best interests. Proxy voting is an integral part of the investment management function. If the manager believes the proposals harm shareholder value, fiduciary duty requires voting against them (in accordance with the firm's proxy voting policies and guidelines). Option A abdicates fiduciary responsibility. Option C is a passive approach that fails to protect client interests when the manager has a clear view.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply fiduciary duty to proxy voting decisions

problems.question: An analyst uses the 'mosaic theory' to develop an investment recommendation. She combines: (1) public financial statements, (2) a published industry report, (3) a conversation with the company's IR department about their general strategy, and (4) her own proprietary analysis of satellite imagery of the company's parking lots. Her recommendation is based on:
options: A) Material nonpublic information because the satellite imagery analysis is not public
B) A valid application of the mosaic theory -- combining public and non-material nonpublic information to reach a material conclusion
C) A violation because she contacted the IR department directly
problems.explanation: Mosaic theory allows analysts to combine public information with non-material nonpublic information (e.g., conversations with company representatives about general strategy) to develop material conclusions. Each individual piece of information is either public or non-material. The analyst's skill in synthesizing these pieces creates value. Satellite imagery analysis of public spaces is the analyst's proprietary work, not MNPI. Option A incorrectly classifies proprietary analysis as MNPI. Option C mischaracterizes normal IR interactions.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply the mosaic theory to distinguish legitimate research from MNPI use

problems.question: A CFA candidate includes the following on her resume: 'Passed all three CFA exam levels on the first attempt. Expected charter award: June 2026.' She has passed Level III but has not yet received the charter. This statement:
options: A) Violates Standard VII(B) because she implies she is a CFA charterholder
B) Is acceptable because she accurately states she passed the exams and provides the expected charter date
C) Violates Standard VII(B) because she cannot reference passing all three levels until the charter is awarded
problems.explanation: CFA candidates and exam passers may factually state their exam status. Saying 'Passed all three CFA exam levels' is a factual statement about exam achievement. Including 'Expected charter award: June 2026' clarifies she is not yet a charterholder. This is consistent with Standard VII(B)'s guidance. Option A is incorrect because she does not claim to be a charterholder. Option C is overly restrictive -- candidates may reference passing exams as long as they do not misrepresent their status.
problems.learningOutcome: Correctly reference CFA exam status without misrepresentation

problems.question: A portfolio manager realizes that a particular stock she recommended has declined significantly and the original investment thesis is no longer valid. However, selling would crystallize a large loss and reduce the account's reported performance. She decides to hold the position. This decision most likely violates:
options: A) Standard III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, and Care because she is prioritizing performance optics over the client's best interest
B) No standard, because holding is a valid investment decision and losses may recover
C) Standard V(A) only, because the original research basis has changed
problems.explanation: Holding a position specifically to avoid crystallizing a loss for performance reporting purposes puts the manager's interests (better performance metrics) ahead of the client's (optimal portfolio positioning). Standard III(A) requires acting in the client's best interest with prudence. If the investment thesis is invalid, continuing to hold is not prudent. The motivation (avoiding reported losses) makes this a clear fiduciary breach. Option B ignores that the stated motivation is cosmetic, not investment-based. Option C identifies a related issue but the primary violation is the fiduciary duty breach.
problems.learningOutcome: Identify fiduciary duty violations related to loss aversion and performance reporting

problems.question: A research analyst copies several paragraphs from another analyst's published report and includes them in her own report without attribution. She changes some words but the ideas and structure are substantially similar. This is a violation of:
options: A) Standard I(C) Misrepresentation -- specifically plagiarism
B) Standard V(B) Communication with Clients -- the report is not clearly presented
C) No standard, because published research is in the public domain
problems.explanation: Standard I(C) Misrepresentation prohibits plagiarism, which includes: copying or closely paraphrasing another's work without attribution, using another's charts/graphs without credit, and presenting others' ideas as one's own. Even though published research is publicly available, the analyst must attribute the source. Minor word changes do not constitute original work. Option B misidentifies the standard. Option C incorrectly conflates public availability with freedom to use without attribution.
problems.learningOutcome: Identify plagiarism as a violation of Standard I(C)

problems.question: A wealth manager has a client who instructs her to invest 80% of the portfolio in a single speculative stock. The client has moderate risk tolerance and a 10-year time horizon. The wealth manager should:
options: A) Follow the client's instructions because the client has the right to direct investments
B) Explain the risks of concentrated positions, document the discussion, and if the client insists, either comply with documentation or consider declining to manage the account
C) Refuse the instruction outright because it violates suitability standards
problems.explanation: Standard III(C) Suitability requires recommendations consistent with the client's circumstances. An 80% concentration in a speculative stock is inconsistent with moderate risk tolerance. The manager should: (1) educate the client about the risks, (2) explain why the allocation is unsuitable, (3) document the conversation thoroughly. If the client insists after full disclosure, the manager may comply with written acknowledgment or may decline to manage the account. Option A abdicates the suitability obligation. Option C is overly rigid -- the manager should engage in dialogue before refusing.
problems.learningOutcome: Navigate suitability requirements when clients request unsuitable investments

problems.question: A quantitative analyst develops a trading algorithm that she uses both for her employer's proprietary trading desk and for her personal trading account (with employer permission). She runs the algorithm for her personal account first each morning before the employer's desk. This arrangement most likely violates:
options: A) Standard VI(B) Priority of Transactions -- the employer's interests should come before personal interests
B) No standard, because the employer has given permission for the personal account
C) Standard IV(A) Loyalty only, because there is no client involved
problems.explanation: Standard VI(B) requires that the employer's and clients' transactions take priority over the member's personal transactions. Running the algorithm personally first allows the analyst to benefit from market impact before the employer's trades, potentially front-running the employer's orders. Employer permission for a personal account does not waive the priority requirement. Option B incorrectly assumes employer permission covers all aspects. Option C partially identifies the issue but VI(B) is the specific, applicable standard.
problems.learningOutcome: Apply priority of transactions rules to personal trading with employer algorithms

problems.question: A sell-side analyst maintains a 'Buy' rating on a company for which her firm serves as lead underwriter for a pending bond offering. She believes the stock is overvalued. She has most likely violated:
options: A) Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity by allowing the investment banking relationship to influence her research
B) No standard, because maintaining a 'Buy' is a subjective judgment call
C) Standard V(B) Communication only, because she failed to disclose the banking relationship
problems.explanation: Standard I(B) requires independence and objectivity. If the analyst believes the stock is overvalued but maintains a 'Buy' rating because the firm benefits from the banking relationship, she has compromised her objectivity. The investment banking fee creates a financial incentive that is distorting her published opinion. Disclosure of the relationship (Option C's suggestion) is necessary but insufficient -- the rating itself must reflect the analyst's genuine view. Option B ignores the clear conflict between private belief and public recommendation.
problems.learningOutcome: Identify independence violations when banking relationships influence research

problems.question: A CFA charterholder moves from one employer to another. She takes with her a detailed client contact list, proprietary models she developed, and performance records from her previous employer. Regarding the items she took:
options: A) She violated Standard IV(A) Loyalty by taking the client list and proprietary models, which are the employer's property, but performance records she personally generated may be acceptable if they do not include confidential client information
B) She is free to take all items because she created them
C) She violated no standards because the information is in her memory
problems.explanation: Under Standard IV(A), members owe loyalty to their employer regarding proprietary information. Client lists and proprietary models developed during employment generally belong to the employer, even if the member created them. Taking these without permission violates the duty of loyalty. Performance records are a grey area -- general performance data that does not reveal client identities may be acceptable, but specific client information is the employer's. Option B ignores the employer's ownership rights over work product. Option C conflates physical materials with memorized information (memory is generally not restricted, but physical copies are).
problems.learningOutcome: Apply employer loyalty requirements when changing employers

blocks.content: **Review Guide:** Focus on areas where you scored below 70%. Key Level II Ethics concepts: MNPI applies regardless of how obtained, mosaic theory combines public + non-material nonpublic information, fair dealing requires systematic allocation (not fee-based), fiduciary duty overrides performance concerns, priority of transactions protects employer/clients before personal accounts, and employer loyalty covers work product (client lists, models) created during employment.
